boatwithrank.name: Oranges
boatwithrank.short_description: Gunter rig Mirror Dinghy

boatwithrank.name: Pintail
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a fine example of her type.

boatwithrank.name: Ceol-Mara
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Coel Mara', or in English Sound of the Sea was built by my Grandfather, Michael Hicks, in 1993/4. She was designed by George Buehler, an American, under the class name 'The Happy Camper of Pogo Pogo' at all of 16.75 feet. We have wondered if she might not be the smallest schooner afloat!

boatwithrank.name: Elley Grey
boatwithrank.short_description: Gaffers and Luggers only St Malo Pilot Cutter

boatwithrank.name: Nell
boatwithrank.short_description: Yacht built on Itchen Ferry lines, burnt out beyond repair in 1968.

boatwithrank.name: Iseult
boatwithrank.short_description: Iseult was built as a 36 ft. cutter for Norman Deakin, who sailed her around Britain in 1910, Seaview to Seaview via Shetland, winning the Royal Cruising Club’s Challenge Cup.

boatwithrank.name: Emma Goody
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Emma Goody' is an open boat of unknown design or builder. She carries the Colchester fishing no. CK48 and was re-rigged with a bawley rig in 1969.

boatwithrank.name: Grace
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Grace' is a Norske 35 gaff cutter designed by John Perryman on the lines of a Colin Archer sailing lifeboat, originally named 'Sujo'.

boatwithrank.name: Polly
boatwithrank.short_description: Fishing in the Irish Sea up to 1987, 'Polly' is a registered historic fishing vessel LL77.

boatwithrank.name: Jabiru
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Jabiru' is a Yarmouth 23 built in 2002.

boatwithrank.name: Comrade
boatwithrank.short_description: Previously known as 'Mariner-A', then 'Marie-Julie', built 1912 by Ferris of Looe for pilchard fishing.

boatwithrank.name: Katrina
boatwithrank.short_description: Thought to have been built in Essex, 1954, it is not known where or by whom. After being salvaged in 1998 she was bought by Tim Frearson who undertook a major refit, converted her to a gaff cutter and re-launched her in 2004.

boatwithrank.name: Syrinx
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Syrinx' is a Kittiwake 14, boat no 28 of 42 (to 2017).

boatwithrank.name: Olga
boatwithrank.short_description: Built by John Bowden of Porthleven, Cornwall, in 1909, 'Olga' worked out of Barry as a pilot cutter until 1917.

boatwithrank.name: Charles Henry Ashley
boatwithrank.short_description: RNLI Watson type lifeboat for Cemaes, Anglesey,  crewed by Coxswain, 2nd Coxswain, Bowman and 12 Oarsmen.

boatwithrank.name: Lufra
boatwithrank.short_description: Lufra is a much travelled Deben Cherub, having been sailed in Scotland and Cornwall, as well as the Scilly Isles

boatwithrank.name: My Alice
boatwithrank.short_description: 'My Alice' was built in the Kidby yard at Brightlingsea, 1907. She is one of only two remaining Kidby smacks ('Charlotte Ellen' is the other). She is registered in Colchester Creek, hence CK348.

boatwithrank.name: Daisy
boatwithrank.short_description: Daisy was owned until 1947 by Norman Aish, who went on to become the commodore of Parkstone YC, Poole

boatwithrank.name: Missy C
boatwithrank.short_description: 12 foot sloop, Clinker built in mahogany on oak with a sliding Gunter rig.

boatwithrank.name: Mary
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Mary' had her second full rebuild by Brian Kennell and Shaun White, Downs Boatyard, Maldon, 1996 - 2000. She is the only surviving example of an Essex oyster smack with a lute stern, reputed to have been built in 1844 and rebuilt in 1900.

boatwithrank.name: Pegasus
boatwithrank.short_description: Previously named Grace, Pegasus spent the first eleven years of her existence ashore in a garden.

boatwithrank.name: Unity
boatwithrank.short_description: Unity's keel was laid in 2013 and she was launched in 2016 in time for the Brest and Douarnenez Festivals. She is a new design by Jon Bray based on a Mevagissey Lugger hull but with a pole masted gaff cutter rig.

boatwithrank.name: Roxanne
boatwithrank.short_description: Roxanne was built for his own use by Vivian Richards a shipwright working for Martin heard during 1992/1993.

boatwithrank.name: Crystal II
boatwithrank.short_description: According to Uffa Fox "Crystal is one of the best, if not the best, cruiser of her size and type ever designed."

boatwithrank.name: Stadats
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Stadats' was built as a Watson class sailing lifeboat 'Frederick & Emma' in 1921. She served at Wick and Amble, rescuing 94 souls, before being sold out of the service.

boatwithrank.name: Christiane of Mersea
boatwithrank.short_description: Sailed from Falmouth by her original owners to her current home port in Croatia, 2005.

boatwithrank.name: Granuaile
boatwithrank.short_description: Home built in back garden from 19995 to 2003\. Has completed 2 full Atlantic crossings in 2006/7 and again 2014/16\. Has travelled as far south as Guyana, being possibly the first Irish yacht to visit here. Currently based in Strangford Lough Northern Ireland.

boatwithrank.name: Nanouk
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nanouk' is a Francis Vivier Aber design.

boatwithrank.name: Swallow
boatwithrank.short_description: Swallow is a Tela, GRP replica of a pursuit boat working out of Barry Port S Wales - inshore pilot boat.

boatwithrank.name: Elwing
boatwithrank.short_description: Elwing was the first Memory 19 to be built with a cabin and a cutter rig

boatwithrank.name: Skian
boatwithrank.home_port: Port St. Mary, Isle of Man
boatwithrank.short_description: Skian is an early Memory 19, purchased as a wreck in 2017, rebuilt as a lugger with water ballast system, re-cycled Romilly 22 mast and new mainsail, launched May 2018.

boatwithrank.name: Sol-Kongen
boatwithrank.short_description: Sol-Kongen is a Sea King yacht, designed by R.H.Patten

boatwithrank.name: Richard Davey
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1913 for the Missions to Seamen, this much-loved yacht was burnt out off the Scillies in the spring of 1973.

boatwithrank.name: Wind Song
boatwithrank.short_description: Wind Song is the first boat built to a Maurice Griffith design.

boatwithrank.name: Merlin
boatwithrank.short_description: Merlin is a Bay Raider Expedition built in 2016

boatwithrank.name: lottie
boatwithrank.short_description: She's a real one-off.

boatwithrank.name: Reynardine
boatwithrank.short_description: Reynardine is an Alan Buchanan design, built in Gweek, Cornwall, 1974.

boatwithrank.name: Gryphon
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Gryphon' is a Bayraider 20 built in 2012. She sails with the Western Australia OGA in Fremantle.

boatwithrank.name: Shoal Waters
boatwithrank.short_description: Charles Stock built Shoal Waters to his own design in 1963 and sailed her on the East Coast of England until his death in 2012.

boatwithrank.name: Chlamys
boatwithrank.short_description: Chlamys is a converted ship's lifeboat.

boatwithrank.name: Venture
boatwithrank.short_description: There is some question over Venture's build date, quoted as 1920-25 or 1890-1910. She was originally a fishing Nobby in North west England.

boatwithrank.name: Electron
boatwithrank.short_description: Essex smack, CK36, was built by Aldous of Brightlingsea in 1909 and rebuilt from the keel up in 1984 by Andy and Dick Harman.

boatwithrank.name: Boy Frank
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Boy Frank' is a Great Yarmouth shrimper, built in 1957 by Gus, Leigh & Boswell. She is sister ship to 'Horace & Hannah'.

boatwithrank.name: Snoopy
boatwithrank.short_description: Snoopy was converted from a ship's lifeboat by the current owner. He has sailed her single-handed to the Azores and back as well as around Britain from the Netherlands twice.

boatwithrank.name: Phoenix
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally built around 1960, she was bought as a derelict hull in 1990, and rebuilt as a gunter sloop.

boatwithrank.name: Lapwing
boatwithrank.short_description: Lapwing is a Broads One Design built in 1925. She has never been rebuilt and until the present owner had never left the Norfolk Broads. Henry Bird took her to Cowes for the OGA Jubilee in 2013.

boatwithrank.name: Cygnet of London
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Cygnet of London' is a gaff rigged yawl, built in 1906 by the Burgoine Brothers of Kingston on Thames to a design by her first owner G. Chalmers. At some time converted to Bermudan she was converted back to her gaff yawl rig in 2006.

boatwithrank.name: Hyacinth
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Hyacinth' was built in 1900 by Aldous of Brightlingsea, for the French family of Mersea. She was used for oyster dredging and remained in the family until the mid 1960s. She was then purchased by Clarke and Carters of Mersea, re-fitted and sold to Mrs. M. Kennell in 1969.

boatwithrank.name: Toucando
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Toucando' was built in Howth, Dublin, by her original owners using a 35 ft. hull by the late Martin Heard of Gaffers and Luggers in Mylor, Cornwall.

boatwithrank.name: John B
boatwithrank.short_description: 'John B' is a Drascombe Driver, with dipping lug rig, built in the mid 1970's.

boatwithrank.name: Young Larry
boatwithrank.short_description: Young Larry is named after Larry, a boat previously owned by her designer Dick Couture. Built of steel, she has sailed in the Mediterranean and also done the Northwest Passage.

boatwithrank.name: Maybird
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed by Fred Shepherd and built by Jack Tyrrell at Arklow, Co. Wicklow, 1937, 'Maybird' has recently returned to her home port, 2018.

boatwithrank.name: Baba Lalji
boatwithrank.short_description: Baba Lilji is a modern Lug Ketch, designed by Nigel Irens

boatwithrank.name: Spirit of Callisto
boatwithrank.short_description: Spirit of Callisto was built by Spirit Yachts in 2013

boatwithrank.name: Lady Ida
boatwithrank.short_description: Currently being restored

boatwithrank.name: Golden Nomad
boatwithrank.short_description: Golden Nomad is a Cornish Crabber Pilot Trader, built and fitted out in 1981 by Cornish Crabbers, Rock, Cornwall. She is a gaff rigged ketch. 30ft. on deck, the largest boat built by Cornish Crabbers.

boatwithrank.name: Maid of Tesa
boatwithrank.short_description: A Vertue built in Middlesborough by Arthur Potter, launched in 1953.

boatwithrank.name: Storm 2
boatwithrank.short_description: Storm 2 is a Mark 1 Cornish Crabber built in 1974. She has spent some time in Holland under the name of Kornuit.

boatwithrank.name: Aurora
boatwithrank.short_description: Aurora is a Cape Cutter 19 built in Rochdale by Bob Brown at Honnor Marine. She is currently based on the Solent.

boatwithrank.name: Halloween
boatwithrank.short_description: Commissioned by Henry Leonard Choppin, on his retirement from the Navy, 'Halloween' was built by Frank Shuttlewood at his boatshed in Paglesham. She was launched 31 October 1950, hence her name.

boatwithrank.name: Larry
boatwithrank.short_description: Commissioned as a "fast cruiser with some racing potential" and launched in 1907, 'Larry' has been cruised and raced around the coasts of the UK, the Mediterranean, Caribbean, north east USA and Canada, Greenland and Norwegian Arctic. After spending two years in Shetland she overwintered 2014/15 in Vilagarcia, Western Spain.

boatwithrank.name: Firefly
boatwithrank.short_description: Firefly was raced in the Solent between 1968 and 1975.

boatwithrank.name: Willow
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally built in 1957 as an RNLI boarding boat, 'Willow' has been converted to sailing rig.

boatwithrank.name: Chough
boatwithrank.short_description: Following major restoration, 'Chough' has varnished Burma teak planking on oak frames with copper and bronze fasteners, bronze floors, lead keel and all new bronze bolts. Her deck is epoxy sheathed.

boatwithrank.name: Lilian
boatwithrank.short_description: A gentleman's yacht built for cruising the Baltic.

boatwithrank.name: Saunterer
boatwithrank.short_description: Saunterer was designed in 1899 and was one of Charles Sibbick's last designs, when he was exploring what he called “fast cruisers'' - she is 16 tons and is 47 feet on the deck (62 with spars) and is extremely strongly built with double oak frames. She has almost all her original timbers including deck and is a good working example of the later evolution of Sibbick’s craft – quite different from his very light displacement racers of the 1890s.

boatwithrank.name: Alpha
boatwithrank.short_description: Alpha was built for fishing under engine, but her lines are those os a traditional sailing bawley

boatwithrank.name: Mermaid
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1860, Mermaid was found as a wreck in 1997 and rebuilt to race again in Falmouth, 2018.  Mermaid is at Gweek Classic Boatyard.

boatwithrank.name: Constance
boatwithrank.short_description: Based on Albert Strange design #45, Wenda of 1899, Constance is a 25 ft. canoe yawl with standing lug main, gunter mizzen and tan sails by Steve Hall, North Sea Sails.

boatwithrank.name: Severn
boatwithrank.short_description: Severn is one of ten Rivers Class Yachts built by William Crossfield and Sons for the Royal Mersey Yacht Club. In 2018 she was bought by Arnside Sailing Club and returned to the village where she was built.

boatwithrank.name: Galatea
boatwithrank.short_description: Galatea is a 1910 design by Albert Strange, the transom version of design noumber 112, "Cherub III"

boatwithrank.name: Playmate
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1898, Playmate was a 30' gaff cutter. Few wooden boats of her size last over 100 years and, probably the oldest boat still sailing in the Bristol Channel, she was broken up in 2010 after being declared 'unseaworthy'.

boatwithrank.name: Airy Mouse
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Airy Mouse' was built in Fowey and launched in 1894 at Watty's yard.

boatwithrank.name: Calyx of Ipswich
boatwithrank.short_description: Calyx of Ipswich was constructed to Lloyds 100A1 and built to laurent Giles Peter Duck design.

boatwithrank.name: Romilda
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Romilda' was owned by Frederick William Hillier for 26 years from 1959. A founder member of the OGA, he and 'Romilda' attended many early Solent events and the Southbourne Sea Scouts often went sailing aboard 'Romilda'. Orignially a trading ship, she was converted to a yacht in 1928.

boatwithrank.name: Masquerade
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Masquerade' is a GRP gaff cutter built in 1999.

boatwithrank.name: Tournesol
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Tournesol' is a Tideway 12 dinghy built in 2005

boatwithrank.name: Heron
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Heron' is a Memory 19, built in 2006.

boatwithrank.name: Bertha
boatwithrank.short_description: Bertha raced in the early East Coast races in the 1960's

boatwithrank.name: Nellie
boatwithrank.short_description: Built to a traditional South Coast design to work as a fishing vessel in Southampton Water, Nellie still has her original layout with fish deck aft.

boatwithrank.name: Albion
boatwithrank.short_description: A Harris built Smack, Albion is in need of a refit.

boatwithrank.name: Beeleigh
boatwithrank.short_description: Beeleigh had a major refit in the 1990's and Mike Hedger returned her to gaff cutter rig in 2005.

boatwithrank.name: Pastime
boatwithrank.short_description: Recorded as being built in Arnside by Crossfield Brothers in 1903 in Lloyds Register. Dave Walters, a folk singer and previous owner, wrote the song "Ballerina" about her, which features in his 1982 Highway album, "Kites". Pastime had an excellent record in the Liverpool Isle of Man Race winning it twice and being place three times in the 1930s. The first photos shows her in the Menai Straits when owned by Peter Price in the mid 60s. and the second when owned by Dave Walters.

boatwithrank.name: Mary Amelia
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Mary Amelia', 1914, is used for cruising and part of the Simper family shellfish business. She is possibly the only genuine working bawley on the East Coast of England.

boatwithrank.name: Katie
boatwithrank.short_description: Katie is one of only two Baltic One Design GRP gaff cutters taken off the hull of gentleman's cutter 'Fortuna'.

boatwithrank.name: Maria
boatwithrank.short_description: Built as a cutter rigged smack in 1866, Maria was used by the Levett family of Tollesbury for about 80 years.

boatwithrank.name: Seaway
boatwithrank.short_description: Featured in Maurice Griffith's Book 'Sixty Years A Yacht Designer', Seaway has been based in Portsmouth all her life. She has suffered two fires but sails on regardless.

boatwithrank.name: Alice
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Alice' is a 25' Itchen Ferry, built 1980. She combines the grace and power of traditional gaff rig with the convenience of a GRP hull.

boatwithrank.name: Tegan
boatwithrank.short_description: She was built to order with inboard engine , delivered by Cornish Crabbers and launched late August 2021

boatwithrank.name: Trixie
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Trixie' is a half-decked clinker sailing dinghy.

boatwithrank.name: Beth
boatwithrank.short_description: Beth was designed for the Boatman Magazine to appeal to amateur builders. She was built to sail at Hickling Broad Sailing Club, Norfolk.

boatwithrank.name: Lilian Rose
boatwithrank.short_description: Moulded from an original in Bangor, North Wales, Lilian Rose was retrieved from the Norfolk Broads in 2001 and rebuilt in Wootton Creek by Hilton Matthews, who passed away in 2008.

boatwithrank.name: North Star
boatwithrank.short_description: 'North Star' is a fine example of Tamarisk 24, built in 1978.

boatwithrank.name: Daydream
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in Lyme Regis, 2014, and nominated in 'Spirit of Tradition' under 40 ft. category: Classic Boat Awards, 2015.

boatwithrank.name: Lollipop
boatwithrank.short_description: Swallow is a Heron Class dinghy, fibreglass hull, purchased on EBay and replacing an earlier wooden Heron which was sadly suffering from terminal rot. Sail number is 9046, she is kept at Coquet Yacht Club, Amble.

boatwithrank.name: Wisper
boatwithrank.short_description: Wisper is a smack yacht designed and built by Tyrell and Young in 1990.

boatwithrank.name: Fanny of Cowes
boatwithrank.short_description: Fanny of Cowes is a well-known member of the OGA's East Coast sailing fleet, still sailing under her original fishing number from 1872. She has a long and interesting history. She's one of only four boats to take part in the first and 50th Anniversary OGA East Coast races and has raced successfully at Cowes since the 1960s.

boatwithrank.name: Little Windflower
boatwithrank.short_description: Little Windflower was built as a yacht in1890. She was owned by Frank Cowper who wrote Sailing Tours. In 1984 John Richardson saied herr to the West Indies and back in 1984-5

boatwithrank.name: Stella Marjorie
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a fine example of her type.

boatwithrank.name: Charlotte Elizabeth
boatwithrank.short_description: Charlotte Elizabeth is a Cornish Crabber 24 built in 1998.

boatwithrank.name: Sea Trout
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sea Trout' is a Drascombe Lugger built in 1991.

boatwithrank.name: SehnSucht
boatwithrank.short_description: SehnSucht is a gaff rigged Finesse 24.

boatwithrank.name: Theresa
boatwithrank.short_description: Built by A. Taylor at Sandown, Isle of Wight in 1907, 'Theresa' was designed by Albert Strange.

boatwithrank.name: Gradely Lass
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Gradely Lass' is a 21' coastal whammel, built by Character Boats in 2009.

boatwithrank.name: Margaret Catchpole
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in Poole as a fishing smack, and converted to a yacht in 1947 at Christchurch, 'Margaret Catchpole' was kept at Pin Mill until 2003 when she was moved to Rochester.

boatwithrank.name: Saint Patrick
boatwithrank.short_description: Rebuilt by Paddy Barry 1974-79 and extensively cruised, 'Saint Patrick' was lost on 21 May 2002 when she broke from her mooring in Glandore Bay.

boatwithrank.name: Faith
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Faith' is a new build within 'historic craft' legislation, built and designed by Fabian Bush at Rowhedge and launched in 2014.

boatwithrank.name: Raven
boatwithrank.short_description: Gaff cutter 'Raven' was designed by Lyle Hess, built in wood by Fred Schotman and launched in 2004.

boatwithrank.name: Lizzie
boatwithrank.short_description: Mayfly Oystercatcher 16 Gaff Rigged Cutter Dayboat

boatwithrank.name: Moorhen
boatwithrank.short_description: Moorhen is a replica Galway Hooker 'a piece of Irish tradition with a Dutch touch', launched in 1996 by her builder, Rik Janssen and built in wood epoxy.

boatwithrank.name: Cat-a-Tonic
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Cat-a-Tonic' is a 12' American Cat Boat.

boatwithrank.name: Deirdre
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Deirdre' (pronounced 'daredra') is a gaff cutter designed by Dennis Jacobs and built by Alexander Gostelow of Boston in 1935. She has been restored to a high standard over the period 2011 - 2015.

boatwithrank.name: Alice
boatwithrank.short_description: Steel bilge keel cutter

boatwithrank.name: Mary Gray
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Mary Gray' is a Z4 Tonner, designed by Harrison Butler and built in 1939.

boatwithrank.name: Sea Nymph
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sea Nymph' is one of 18 boats built beside the River Deben at Eversons, Woodbridge, Suffolk during the 1920s. She is based in the Netherlands.

boatwithrank.name: Menai Gypsy
boatwithrank.short_description: A Norfolk Gypsy, built 1996, 19ft plus bowsprit, now home on Anglesey North Wales. She has spent her life sailing from Anglesey.

boatwithrank.name: Nanette
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nanette' was built at Arnside in 1933. She has a classic yacht form, with curved raking transom on a counter, typical of the Crossfield yard.

boatwithrank.name: Half Moon
boatwithrank.short_description: Half Moon was built by her first owner over a period of five years.

boatwithrank.name: Puffin Bach
boatwithrank.short_description: A fine example of a Tamarisk 24 class topsail gaff cutter.

boatwithrank.name: Misty
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Misty' is a gunter cutter, built in 1931 by Lavers of Dartmouth.

boatwithrank.name: Shireen
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Shireen' is a Clyde 19/24, built in 1900 in the Royal Burgh of Rutherglen by Ewing McGruer. Designed by Alfred Mylne she has been restored and relaunched, May 2017.

boatwithrank.name: Frolic
boatwithrank.place_built: Hegartys Yard Oldcourt Skibereen West Cork Ireland
boatwithrank.short_description: Frolic is a traditional gaff cutter, kept in Fenit, North Kerry.

boatwithrank.name: Winifred
boatwithrank.short_description: Winifred is a replica of 1/2 rater Wee Winn, commissioned in 1892 by Blair Cochrane of Bembridge, Isle of Wight for Winifred Sutton.

boatwithrank.name: Saorsa
boatwithrank.short_description: Original design Drascombe Drifter - bilge keel trailable cabin cruiser

boatwithrank.name: Satellite
boatwithrank.short_description: Satellite is a Golant Gaffer built by her first owner and launched in 2017.

boatwithrank.name: Samphire
boatwithrank.short_description: She is an early example and the smallest of Laurent giles designs.

boatwithrank.name: Fleur
boatwithrank.short_description: Fleur has standing lug/mizzen, bowsprit and bumpkin.

boatwithrank.name: Daisy
boatwithrank.short_description: With a hull purchased from North Cornwall Marine, 1984, by Ted Smith who fitted her out, 'Impudence' was sailing in 1986. After several name changes, she emerged from a major refit, 2011 - 2013 as 'Daisy'.

boatwithrank.name: Mairi Bhan
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed as 26 foot Gaff Sloop and converted to Bermudan rig

boatwithrank.name: Lily
boatwithrank.short_description: Fitted out by her owner from new between 1998 and 2002, 'Lily' is the first boat from a Tyrell & Young mould to be fitted with racing rig.

boatwithrank.name: Hester
boatwithrank.short_description: Hester is a 20ft Tosher built by Martin Heard in1994.

boatwithrank.name: Halewyn
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Haleywn' is a Bermudan sloop, with mahogany hull, built 1960 at St Malo by Labbe.

boatwithrank.name: Nelly Mathilde
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nelly Mathilde' was named after the last Swedish commercial three-masted barque. Built at Simrishamn, Sweden by Knut Aspegren as a blue-water cruiser, her designer, Jac M. Iversen served his apprenticeship under Colin Archer.

boatwithrank.name: Vera Causa
boatwithrank.home_port: Port Clywedog Sailing Club  Llanidloes, Powys.
boatwithrank.short_description: Vera Causa is a Ridgeway Marine Skipper 17 built in 1979.

boatwithrank.name: Faith
boatwithrank.short_description: In 2001, 'Faith' was ashore in a derelict state.

boatwithrank.name: Saltair
boatwithrank.short_description: Saltair's hull was substantially rebuilt at Testers Yard, Oare, Kent in approximately 1987-8. The rebuild was completed 1999 to 2002 by Mayland and Mundon in Essex.

boatwithrank.name: Mary Ritchie
boatwithrank.short_description: Golant gaffer, built on the River Fowey 1992, Mary Ritchie took part in the OGA Round Britain Challenge in 2013, sailing from Heybridge Basin to Falmouth.

boatwithrank.name: Jan Mayen
boatwithrank.short_description: Built at Whisstocks Boatyard, Woodbridge, Suffolk in 1964, 'Jan Mayen' is a 29' motorsailor now berthed in the Solent.

boatwithrank.name: Bona
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Bona', a bawley built in 1903 by Aldous of Brightlingsea is frequently seen sailing and racing on the East Coast of England.

boatwithrank.name: Inanda
boatwithrank.short_description: Inanda is a Deben four-tonner, built at Woodbridge in 1949.

boatwithrank.name: Widget
boatwithrank.short_description: A keel / centreboard day sailer designed by Joel White, based on Nat Herreshoff's Buzzards Bay 12.5 from 1914.

boatwithrank.name: Cygnus
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a fine example of her type.

boatwithrank.name: Madeline
boatwithrank.short_description: Built c.1896, there are some gaps in what we know about 'Madeline' . . .

boatwithrank.name: Scandal
boatwithrank.short_description: Scandal is a Tamarisk 22 built in 1974.

boatwithrank.name: Star
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed and built by the Alfred Wade Yard, Isle of Wight, 1907, Star's first owner was the Royal Naval College. Following an eventful history, including sailing in the first OGA East Coast Race, her home port is now on Lake Maggiore, Italy.

boatwithrank.name: Alando
boatwithrank.short_description: Alando was built by Aldous in 1923, originally registerd as CK1. She was removed from the register in 1938 and her history until the 1970s remains a mystery.

boatwithrank.name: Rosa and Ada
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Rosa and Ada', a Whitstable oyster smack, was built in 1908 by Collar Bros., Whitstable, Kent. After conversion to a yacht in the 1950s she was taken to Scotland where she still sails as a charter vessel.

boatwithrank.name: Bonify
boatwithrank.short_description: Bonify was built between 1980 and 1993 to the lines of the American Carol class cutter, designed in 1924 by John Hanna as a big sister to his more famous Tahiti ketch.

boatwithrank.name: Carrie
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Carrie' is a Heard 23, based on the Clyde.

boatwithrank.name: Mary Ellen
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Mary Ellen' was built in 1934 by Kidby and Sons, Brightlingsea, Essex. As builders of fast smacks they built her to their own design as a gentleman's yacht for a local farmer. Her hull takes the shape of an Essex smack, but with a spoon bow and transom stern. She has been cruised extensively.

boatwithrank.name: Barbarossa
boatwithrank.short_description: Built by Rob aged 20 and Sue 16, 'Barbarossa' was launched 26 June, 1976. Rob and Sue were married a week later and lived on board, bringing up their two children.

boatwithrank.name: Madcap
boatwithrank.short_description: Reputed to be the only remaining, original Bristol Pilot Cutter still in commission, originally built in 1875, Madcap has a remarkable history.

boatwithrank.name: Calypso
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Calypso' is a beautiful Bermudan cutter, built Falmouth in the 1930s.

boatwithrank.name: Glory
boatwithrank.short_description: Glory is a Cornish Crabber Yawl built in 1989.

boatwithrank.name: Shearwater
boatwithrank.short_description: Shearwater is a 16square class.

boatwithrank.name: Blue Note
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Blue Note' is a replica of an East Coast smack's boat, 12' length, sail area 7.1 sq m. Built by Brian Kennel in 2013.

boatwithrank.name: Maid Marion
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1925, originally named 'Westward', she was re-named in 1935. During the Second World War she set out to assist in the Dunkirk evacuation, but was diverted to le Havre.

boatwithrank.name: Margaret Ann
boatwithrank.short_description: Margaret Ann is a Hillyard 2 1/2 tonner built in 1939

boatwithrank.name: Annie Kay
boatwithrank.short_description: Annie- Kay is a Heard 23 built in 1995.

boatwithrank.name: Agate
boatwithrank.short_description: Re-named 'Agate' in April 2015, previously known as 'Gemma'. Built le Havre, 1911, she was a flush decked gaff cutter with skylight and deep cockpit, but converted to cruiser with self draining cockpit in around 1972.

boatwithrank.name: Naomh Cronan
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Naomh Cronan' is built from the lines of Galway Hooker, 'Morning Star'.

boatwithrank.name: Rosie
boatwithrank.short_description: Rosie, ex Rosie G is a Cornish Crabbers Pilot Cutter built in 1990.

boatwithrank.name: Amanda
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Amanda' was built in 1920 by Crossfields of Arnside. She is a Morecambe Bay prawner.

boatwithrank.name: Twinkler
boatwithrank.short_description: Believed to be the first boat built by David Hillyard,1922, for the first London Boat Show.

boatwithrank.name: Nancy Blackett
boatwithrank.short_description: Nancy Blackett was built in 1931 by Hillyards of Littlehampton. Between 1934 and 1938 she was owned by the children's author, Arthur Ransome. She inspired his book 'We Didn't Mean to Go to Sea', in which she is featured as the 'Goblin'. She also appears in its sequel 'Secret Water'. She is now owned by the Nancy Blackett Trust.

boatwithrank.name: Bunny
boatwithrank.short_description:
'Bunny' is a 15 ft Sea Otter Canoe Yawl built by David Moss at Skippool Creek in 1989, based on the designs of Albert Strange and the Humber Canoe Yawls.

She is somewhat unusual as she is gunter rigged rather than the normal lug rig.

boatwithrank.name: Lily Lodestone
boatwithrank.short_description: Lily Lodestone was designed by Percy Dalton on the lines of the Falmouth Oyster Dredger.

boatwithrank.name: Melmore
boatwithrank.short_description: Melmore, built in 1928, won the 1975 Commemorative Fastnet Race, completed a circumnavigation of Britain and Ireland in 1978 and the Two Star in 1981.

boatwithrank.name: Swift II
boatwithrank.short_description: Swift II is a Twister, designed by Kim Holman and built in 1980.

boatwithrank.name: Fargo II
boatwithrank.short_description: Fargo II is a Salar 40 class Bermudan yacht

boatwithrank.name: Doris
boatwithrank.short_description: A Canoe Yawl designed by David Moss that has similarities to George Holmes (eg EEL) and Albert Strange's Humber Yawls

boatwithrank.name: Thumble
boatwithrank.short_description: Thumble is a Mark 1 Cornish Crabber.

boatwithrank.name: Dusky Maid
boatwithrank.short_description: Dusky Maid was a Falmouth Quay Punt built in 1908

boatwithrank.name: Rainbow
boatwithrank.short_description: After cruising the Caribbean and competing in classic yacht rallies for 14 years, 'Rainbow' returned to the UK for extensive restoration work in Poole.

boatwithrank.name: Anny Ann
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Anny Ann' is a 1989 Tamarisk 29, a traditional long keeled yacht with gaff rig.

boatwithrank.name: Periwinkle
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Periwinkle' is a Tamarisk 24 designed by David Cannel and built by Glyn White of Fowey in 1983. Glyn was a former cabinet maker and thus not surprisingly she was finished to a high standard. The hull was made in GRP and the deck in marine ply, the rest in teak and iroko.

boatwithrank.name: Serinette
boatwithrank.short_description: Serinette is a Finesse 24, originally built as a Bermdan cutter and converted to a gaff in 2016.

boatwithrank.name: Espanola
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally named Irene II, Espanola was built in 1902 by S F Bond of Birkenhead, rigged as a gaff cutter.

boatwithrank.name: Spinaway X
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Spinaway X' is an early Plymouth Hooker built in Looe in 1889.

boatwithrank.name: Pajaro
boatwithrank.short_description: Pajaro is a very pretty 23ft Bermudan rigged classic wooden dayboat.

boatwithrank.name: Merlin
boatwithrank.short_description:
'Merlin' was a Falmouth Quay Punt, converted to a yacht. After Chris Beane sold her the new owner embarked on a major refit but never completed it.

Broken up in 2019.

boatwithrank.name: Lucy of Mylor
boatwithrank.short_description: Previously known as 'Lucy', and built by Martin Heard in 1985 she has sailed extensively, visiting Brest in 1992, 1996 and 2004, Holland in 1997 and 2005 and several Falmouth Festivals.

boatwithrank.name: Kamala
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Kamala' was designed by Barry Pope after the local Danish fishing craft. The rig is taken from a Helsignor Pilot Boat

boatwithrank.name: Essex Melody
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Essex Melody' was designed and built by John Scarlett, first secretary of the OGA, along the lines of the first JOG (Junior Offshore Group) yacht 'Sopranino'.

boatwithrank.name: Gelvynek
boatwithrank.short_description: Gelvynek is a dipping lug day boat by a Francois Vivier

boatwithrank.name: Esme
boatwithrank.short_description: Esme is a Mark 1 Crabber, of unknown build date.

boatwithrank.name: Mutual Friend
boatwithrank.short_description: Mutual Friend is a modern GRP version of an East Coast Smack Yacht

boatwithrank.name: Chloe
boatwithrank.short_description: Chloe is a Golant Gaffer built by Nick Hayward.

boatwithrank.name: Rock of Ages
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Rock of Ages' is an ex-inshore fishing boat with resemblance to Sheringham Beach Boats and Lifeboats, colloquailly described as a 'Shannocker'.

boatwithrank.name: Sea Jay
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sea Jay' is a Stornaway 18' designed by Derek Ellard of Scruffie Boats, Australia and built by Oz Marine in 2003.

boatwithrank.name: Virtue Fidelis
boatwithrank.short_description: The Vertue was designed by Laurent Giles and Partners and had a length overall of 25.5 feet.

boatwithrank.name: Ostara
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Ostara' is a West Briton design built in 1950. She was called 'Framar ll' from 1951 to 1953.

boatwithrank.name: Meagan
boatwithrank.short_description: Second of an Ed Burnett designed new class. No 1 was named 'Zinnia', 'Meagan' was built 1998 to 2000.

boatwithrank.name: Tantina II
boatwithrank.short_description: Featured in Yachting World as a good cruiser that can race under JOG/RORC rules, Tantina II is heavily built and survived a Force 11 at Rockall. She has cruised from France to Shetlands and as far as The Azores.

boatwithrank.name: Cariad
boatwithrank.short_description: Cariad is a Cornish Crabber 26.

boatwithrank.name: Freda
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Freda' was moulded from the 'Sir William Priestley' the Morecambe Bay Prawner Association lifeboat.

boatwithrank.name: Vilma
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Vilma' was built as a fishing boat on the Baltic coast of Denmark in 1934.

boatwithrank.name: Stout
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Stout' was built 1907 for the Royal Pilot Administration (Kungliga Lotsstyrelsen) for service in Öresound under sail or power propulsion. In a 'For sale' ad. in 2006, she was described as 'a little ship with plenty of character'.

boatwithrank.name: Barbara Agnes
boatwithrank.short_description: Barbara Agnes is a Heard 28, built in Mylor, 1992.

boatwithrank.name: Bold Hamster
boatwithrank.short_description: New Blossom Class, designed by John Leather and described by him as 'my ideal small gaff cutter'. Built by Ian Brown, of Rowhedge, Essex, 1965. She's described as a characterful and comfortable weekender, with good sitting headroom.

boatwithrank.name: Eilun
boatwithrank.short_description: Believed to be a White Bros. of Itchen build, Eilun is the last known survivor of her class.

boatwithrank.name: Felicis
boatwithrank.short_description: Felicis is a Mitchell Sea Ranger built in Brightlingsea; number 110 with Gunter rig.

boatwithrank.name: Mischief
boatwithrank.short_description: Mischief is a Cornish Crabber 22 built in 2009.

boatwithrank.name: Dreva
boatwithrank.short_description: Dreva was built in 1936 for George Romney Fox (1898 – 1968), a Falmouth timber merchant. Designed by Nigel Warrington Smyth, a talented amateur designer based in the West Country.  Her bold sheer is said to be typical of his designs

boatwithrank.name: Widgeon
boatwithrank.short_description: Widgeon is a Gleoiteog class Galway hooker built in Connemara in 1938.

boatwithrank.name: Annabel J
boatwithrank.short_description: Annabel J has been described as a replica Bristol pilot cutter, but new materials have been used where appropriate combining performance of the renowned pilot cutters with a fine modern vessel.

boatwithrank.name: D Ernest John C
boatwithrank.short_description: Bursledon Gig Rowing Lugger ketch.

boatwithrank.name: Hebe
boatwithrank.short_description: Hebe is a Romilly built in 2001

boatwithrank.name: Alicia
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Alicia' was built by George French at Tucker Brown of Burnham on Crouch in 1936.

boatwithrank.name: Widget
boatwithrank.short_description: Emsworth Lugger. 9ft 6ins lug dinghy on a launching trolley. Tailor made boat cover by James Lawrence.

boatwithrank.name: White Heather
boatwithrank.short_description: Converted to a lugger in 1997.

boatwithrank.name: William
boatwithrank.short_description: 'William', launched in 1992, is one of the glassfibre replicas taken from the mould of the 'Sir William Priestley', the Morecambe Fisherman’s lifeboat.

boatwithrank.name: Ellen
boatwithrank.short_description: Ellen, a Tamarisk 24 replica Itchen Ferry gaff cutter, described by one of her owners as 'a delight to sail', was built in 1983.

boatwithrank.name: Frith
boatwithrank.short_description: 10-foot gunter-rigged dinghy built in England in 1950s. Crossed Atlantic on deck of 48-foot yawl Klang II. Saved from chainsaw in late ’70s with two holes in bottom. Sails by North Sea Sails’ Steve Hall.

boatwithrank.name: Memory
boatwithrank.short_description: Her first owner, Tony Robinson, designed the renowned Memory class, built by Salterns Boats.

boatwithrank.name: Mora
boatwithrank.short_description: Mora is a Norfolk Gypsy built in 1994, hull number 60, without modification.

boatwithrank.name: Privateer
boatwithrank.short_description: Privateer has been described as a 'traditional old gaffer', built in 1931 as a fishing smack and later converted to a yacht at the boatyard in Boston.

boatwithrank.name: Clytie
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Clytie' still sails on the River Deben, where she was originally built in 1922.

boatwithrank.name: Questina
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Questina' is a home built boat, between 1999 and 2002.

boatwithrank.name: Baggywrinkle
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed and built by her first owner, Iain McBride, 'Baggywrinkle' was launched in 2002. Originally built as a yawl, rig has been modified to a single mast with standing lug.

boatwithrank.name: Zinnia
boatwithrank.short_description: Zinnia is the first of the Zinnia Class. She sailed to the Caribbean and back without an engine in 1999 - 2000, Zinnia was fitted with an inboard engine in 2003.

boatwithrank.name: Sugar Creek
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sugar Creek' is a 30' Colin Archer design. She took part in the first East Coast Old Gaffers Race in 1963.

boatwithrank.name: Sùlaire
boatwithrank.short_description: Sùlaire is a fine example of a Brian Kennel Smack Boat

boatwithrank.name: Zeezot
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Zeezot' is a lobster sloop used in the Golfe du Morbihan, later refitted for leisure use in Nieuwpoort Shipyard Verhaeghe.

boatwithrank.name: Naida
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Naida' was built by her first owner. Her design is based on the mid 19th century 'Pinky Ketches' of the East Coast of the USA. She is built almost entirely from timber collected from the Great Storm of 1987, all of this came from within a mile of where she was built.

boatwithrank.name: Caplin
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Caplin' was designed and built by Andrew Anderson & Son of Penarth, Wales, in 1937.

boatwithrank.name: Sea Dog
boatwithrank.short_description: She's a real one-off.

boatwithrank.name: Sunlight
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sunlight' was the first of the 'Eastcountryman 33' class, built by Paul Winch in 1980 prior to forming his company in the same name.

boatwithrank.name: Morwenna
boatwithrank.short_description: Morwenna is a Heard 28 built in 1988. The interior was fitted out by her first owner, Dave Baggett.

boatwithrank.name: Wingoes
boatwithrank.short_description: Mentioned by Eric Hiscock in Cruising Under Sail

boatwithrank.name: Morwenna
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Morwenna', then called 'Salem' was exported to the USA when built and shipped back to the UK for her second owners in 2011 since when she has cruised the West Country.

boatwithrank.name: Chiranga
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Chiranga' is a ferrocement gaff ketch based on the Lemsteraak Dutch Sailing Barge design.

boatwithrank.name: Aeolus
boatwithrank.short_description: One off plank on edge design inspired by G Watson. She was built and raced off San Diego. She had a major re-build in 1982 and was shipped to UK in the early 2000s.

boatwithrank.name: Daisy
boatwithrank.short_description: Open cockpit, inboard Yanmar 2GM. Small Falmouth Working Boat.

boatwithrank.name: High Barbaree
boatwithrank.short_description: High Barbaree was built in 2001 and has cruised extensively since then in the Netherlands, Baltic and France from a base on the English East Coast then the Solent. She participated in the OGA Round Britain Challenge in 2013.

boatwithrank.name: Marguerite
boatwithrank.short_description: Only sister of the prototype for the Howth 17, 'Ethine'.

boatwithrank.name: Charlie
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1997, 'Charlie' is of GRP construction in the hull and decks, with extensive use of hardwood finishes. 'Charlie's' home port is the Cardiff Bay Yacht Club in Cardiff Bay.

boatwithrank.name: Kelpie
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally built in 1903, Kelpie was converted back to cutter from yawl in 1993.

boatwithrank.name: Ranger
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1933, 'Ranger' is still sailed in Sydney, Australia by OGA member Bill Gale, the son of her designer, EC Gale.

boatwithrank.name: Harvester
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Harvester' is a North Norfolk Whelker, built by Emery of Sheringham in 1951, and restored by David Hewitt of Blakeney in 2001.

boatwithrank.name: Awara
boatwithrank.short_description: A Tahiti ketch

boatwithrank.name: Bess
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Bess' is a 14’, clinker hulled open boat built in 1947. She is kept on a swinging mooring at Slaughden, Suffolk in the summer and returns to a garage for the winter. Major overhaul Everson's, Aldeburgh and self 2019-20.

boatwithrank.name: Lista Light
boatwithrank.short_description:
Norwegian fishing vessel, converted to private sailing vessel in 1974. Spruce on spruce, Ribs 9 x 5.5 inches at 18” centres.

Perkins 6345.

boatwithrank.name: Valerian
boatwithrank.short_description: She's a real one-off.

boatwithrank.name: Missy G
boatwithrank.short_description: Francois Vivier designed, home built Gaff rigged yawl.

boatwithrank.name: Charlotte
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed and built by Crossfield of Arnside in 1893, 'Charlotte' is a Morecambe Bay Prawner. In 2019, she is undergoing a major restoration in the midlands

boatwithrank.name: Pied Piper of Burnham
boatwithrank.short_description: Pied Piper of Burnham is a Bermudan Sloop designed by Alan Buchanan and built by Alan Platt in 1961

boatwithrank.name: Reverie M
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Reverie M' is based on a small Falmouth workboat and building started in 1986.

boatwithrank.name: Arriana
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Arriana' is a Tamarisk 29 based on the Falmouth Quay Punt. 'She took part in the OGA Netherlands 10th Anniversary Tour, 2014.

boatwithrank.name: Daisy
boatwithrank.short_description: Memory 19 gaff rigged dayboat. Open cockpit version with two berths under foredeck.

boatwithrank.name: Tir na nOg of Howth
boatwithrank.short_description: Tir na n'Og of Howth is a Heard 28 built in 1992 by Gaffers and Luggers. Her home port, as her name, is Howth Yacht Club, Dublin Bay.

boatwithrank.name: Camay
boatwithrank.short_description: Camay was a Bermudan rigged sloop designed by J Laurent Giles. She is a Normandy Class Yacht - some have described her as a 'stretched' Vertue. She was sold as a hulk to be broken up in 2019.

boatwithrank.name: TAJ
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 2005, 'TAJ' has a fibreglass hull made from a mould derived from an original clinker-built dinghy, dating back to about 1955.

boatwithrank.name: Plugger
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Plugger' is a 17' 6" quarter decked clinker mahogany on oak dayboat from the 1920s.

boatwithrank.name: LizAnna
boatwithrank.short_description: LizAnna was the first BC23 to have an inboard engine fitted and was exhibited on their stand at the 2013 show.

boatwithrank.name: Eagle
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Eagle' is a classic 30' gaff cutter, pitch pine on oak. She was built in 1915 at Pin Mill, Suffolk for the express purpose of wiping out all the opposition in local regattas.

boatwithrank.name: Sallie
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sallie' is a Class 2 smack, built in 1907 by Aldous of Brightlingsea. She is one of only a small number of Colchester smacks still sailed in the traditional manner, without an engine.

boatwithrank.name: Peggy
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Peggy' is an ex working prawning boat, believed to have been built about 1910 by Crossfields at Arnside,  Morcambe Bay. She worked out of Maryport under registration number MT13.

boatwithrank.name: Lone Wolf
boatwithrank.short_description: One off design probably based on the Poole fishing boats/pilot boats of the time. Cruised to the Baltic before First World War and taken down through the French canals in the winter of 1919-20 returning back to South Coast of England in 1920. Moved to East Coast just before Second World War and thought to have spent the war at Pin Mill. Converted to Bermudan in 1950 and back to gaff in 1982. Moved back to the South Coast in 1983 and underwent a major refit 1984-7, Lone Wolf has been a regular participant in Solent area events ever since.

boatwithrank.name: Wren
boatwithrank.short_description: 19' half decked boat designed by Francois Vivier. Home built.

boatwithrank.name: Restful
boatwithrank.short_description: Classic open punt designed to live in davits, rows a crew of three with four passengers. She has lived on the Isle of Wight for 110 years until January 2008 and was in the same family for 70 of these years.

boatwithrank.name: Al Said
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a fine example of her type.

boatwithrank.name: Faithful
boatwithrank.short_description: Faithful is a Cornish Crabber Yawl built in 1993

boatwithrank.name: Black Bess
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Black Bess' is an Itchen ferry built by Feltham in 1873.

boatwithrank.name: Speedwell
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Speedwell', was built 1919 by Crossfields of Arnside. Her first owner was Percy Baxter, Morecambe Bay fisherman. Her fishing no. registration history indicates she fished from Whitehaven, Fleetwood and Lancaster. 2019 finds her undergoing a major restoration in Liverpool.

boatwithrank.name: Summer Breeze
boatwithrank.short_description: Summer Breeze is a Cornish Crabber 26 built in 2011

boatwithrank.name: Ida of Falmouth
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Ida of Falmouth' is a Heard 35 Falmouth Quay punt, built to Jeff Baker's plans in 2001.

boatwithrank.name: Ruffler
boatwithrank.short_description: Ruffler is a Memory 19

boatwithrank.name: Storm
boatwithrank.short_description: Storm is a shrimping bawley but was never used for fishing; she was always a yacht. She was owned twice by Maurice Griffiths and features in his books.

boatwithrank.name: Cormorant
boatwithrank.short_description: Engineless gaff yawl built 1911 by Lukes of Hamble

boatwithrank.name: Picotee II
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a fine example of her type.

boatwithrank.name: Odd Times III
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Odd Times' comes from West Mersea where there has been a fishing boat of that name since the early 19th century. In 2019, she's moored on the Hamble River, in Hampshire.

boatwithrank.name: Maryll
boatwithrank.short_description: One of the last Nobbys built by Crossfields of Arnside, June 1937, Maryll was registered as a yacht in 1948.

boatwithrank.name: Phyllis
boatwithrank.short_description: Phyllis is the only example of the Royal Mersey Restricted Class currently afloat.

boatwithrank.name: Pippin
boatwithrank.short_description: Pippin is an epoxy ply Swallow Bayraider Yawl with water ballast and a centreboard.

boatwithrank.name: Tramontana
boatwithrank.short_description: Tramontana is a Harrison Butler Cayuca design built in 1934.

boatwithrank.name: Boadicea
boatwithrank.short_description: The oldest smack on the East Coast, and possibly the oldest sailing vessel in Europe, or the world, she was rebuilt by Mike Frost in the 1960s and is currently owned and sailed by two of his grandchildren.

boatwithrank.name: Wender
boatwithrank.short_description: Built initially as a dayboat, Wender has low freeboard but has cruised thousands of miles.

boatwithrank.name: Anita
boatwithrank.short_description: Anita was built as a fishing boat, then converted for leisure

boatwithrank.name: Fritha
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Fritha, a Norfolk Gypsy, has been sailed in the Netherlands and East and South Coasts of England.

boatwithrank.name: Sirius
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Sirius' 16' gunter rigged, clinker cabin cruiser, built Faversham by Dick Dadson in 1968.

boatwithrank.name: Eider
boatwithrank.short_description: Eider is a Broads One Design built in 2004 by Kingsley Farrington

boatwithrank.name: Skylark
boatwithrank.short_description: Built as a pleasure boat for Clacton Pier, she was registered for fishing in 1905 and fished up until the 1950's.

boatwithrank.name: Cloud Walker
boatwithrank.short_description: Fine lined dayboat, possibly N American influenced.

boatwithrank.name: Marihona
boatwithrank.short_description: Sister ship to 'Vixen', 'Marihona' was built for blue water cruising and has undertaken several Atlantic crossings and voyages.

boatwithrank.name: Mnemosyne
boatwithrank.short_description: Mnemosyne is a Memory 19 built in 2007 by Saltern Boat Builders.

boatwithrank.name: Baldrick
boatwithrank.short_description: Baldrick is an open version of the Memory and has been comprehensively re-furbished by Salterns Boatbuilders on the Hamble.

boatwithrank.name: Carlotta
boatwithrank.short_description: Bristol Channel pilot cutter, 'Carlotta', built in 1899 has a fascinating history and has been sailing on the Pacific northwest of North America following an extensive refit, 2004. Following another major refit and new owner, Michael Field, she has returned to the Southampton area, UK, 2017.

boatwithrank.name: Orca
boatwithrank.short_description: A self built open canoe used for club events and longer expeditions.

boatwithrank.name: Penelope
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Penelope' is a Tela Yacht, 16' gaff day-sailer, built in 2012.

boatwithrank.name: Henrietta
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Henrietta' is the type of boat in the founders' minds of the OGA. Owned by Phil Dan, she entered the first East Coast Race in 1963.

boatwithrank.name: Fidelity
boatwithrank.home_port: Royal Quays Marina, North Shields, Newcastle upon Tyne
boatwithrank.short_description: Custom build based on Colin Archer Kattegatt 26

boatwithrank.name: The John and Elsie
boatwithrank.short_description: The John and Elsie' is a Tela, 16' 6" gaff-rigged dayboat. The class was built from a mould taken from a 3/4 decked work boat built in 1911, a Seeker Boat working out of Barry Docks.

boatwithrank.name: Lillibullero
boatwithrank.short_description: Lillibullero is one of many boats on the East Coast of England who has crossed the North Sea and back several times throughout her history. Built in Boston, Linconlshire, in 1932 she was bought by a Dutchman for his honeymoon and in 2009 returned to the River Stour. Her owner returned to the Netherlands in 2014 for the OGA 'Cross Country Cruise'.

boatwithrank.name: Ianthe
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Ianthe' has spent all her life at Christchurch Sailing Club.

boatwithrank.name: Natural Selection
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally called 'Vector' before her launch but then changed to 'Patience', she was sold in 2006 and again in June 2009. Her name was changed  to 'Ellenor Josephine' when she was registered in November 2010.

boatwithrank.name: Capella
boatwithrank.short_description: Capella is a 9 ton Hillyard built in Littlehampton. She has a canoe sterned carvel built hull constructed of pitch pine on oak frames and backbone. Her bright work is a mixture of mahogany and teak.

boatwithrank.name: Howay
boatwithrank.short_description: Howay is a Shetland double-ender work boat.

boatwithrank.name: Dragonfly
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Dragonfly' is an American built Freedom 33 Cat Ketch built 1981 of GRP using the balsa cored method of construction making a very strong but lighter hull than solid GRP.

boatwithrank.name: Nona Me
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nona Me' is a Bay Raider 17, built by Steve Jones. Her OGA handicap has been calculated by Solent Gaffers as .789 (2018).

boatwithrank.name: Kestrel
boatwithrank.short_description: Kestrel is understood to have been built in 1891 by John White of Cowes. She was largely rebuilt 1997 - 2001. Of the original boat only two thirds of the planking, tiller, mast and boom remain.

boatwithrank.name: Sonamara
boatwithrank.short_description: Sonamara is a Cornish Yawl, built 1992.

boatwithrank.name: Pierce Eye
boatwithrank.short_description: Pierce Eye is a Walton One Design, built in 1921 by Brooke and Hall with sail no. 7.

boatwithrank.name: Greensleeves
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Greensleeves' is a 19' Memory 'with two 7' berths, a cooker, sink, red and black bucket, a good sail wardrobe and two outboards'.

boatwithrank.name: Fleetwing
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Fleetwing' was the 2nd Harrison Butler Cruising yacht built, and the oldest now surviving. Although originally called 'Seagull', she had been renamed 'Fleetwing' only a year later, in 1914.

boatwithrank.name: Kingfisher of Hamford Water
boatwithrank.short_description: Kingfisher of Hamford Water is a sailing dinghy, probably one of the last sailing vessels built at Chatham Naval Dockyard.

boatwithrank.name: Persis
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Persis' was built in 1987, a Cornish Crabber Pilot Cutter 30. In 2014 she sailed to Falmouth via the Isles of Scilly to see the Pilot Cutter Championships in St Mawes.

boatwithrank.name: Ibis
boatwithrank.short_description: Ibis was converted from a fishing smack to a yacht in the 1930's

boatwithrank.name: Freya II
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in pitch pine on oak by Kidby of Brightlingsea, 1898, she was cruised on the Solent and Canal du Midi and active in OGA events 1960 - mid 1980s.

boatwithrank.name: Bonita
boatwithrank.short_description: Bonita was built in 1888 at Arnside in Cumbria. Owned by the same family since 1937, she's a very elegant 'old lady' and successfully completed the OGA Round Britain Challenge circumnavigation of Britain in 2013, her 125th birthday year.

boatwithrank.name: Vagrant Gypsy
boatwithrank.short_description:
Red sails
Cream hull with blue strake

boatwithrank.name: Malin
boatwithrank.home_port: St Mawes, currently laid up ashore in Somerset.
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Malin' cruises the coast between the Lizard and Exmouth, usually spending the summer holidays in St Mawes.

boatwithrank.name: SIF
boatwithrank.short_description: Named after the Scandinavian goddess, SIF was built in Odense, Denmark, 1894. An engine-less gaff cutter, she was re-rigged as a schooner, embarking on an unsuccessful round the world cruise and ending in Plymouth, England, 1934. Bought by an ice manufacturer who re-named her 'Icicle IV' she had her first motor installed.

boatwithrank.name: Morwenna
boatwithrank.short_description: Morwenna is a Cornish Shrimper built in 2003.

boatwithrank.name: Sawsan
boatwithrank.short_description: GRP gaff rigged cutter designed by Paul Gartside based on oyster boats found in Cornwall.

boatwithrank.name: Frances Webber
boatwithrank.short_description:
Alex Kimble commissioned 'Alice Pellow' from new in 1989, naming her after his Granny.

Les May re-named her in 2019 after his Grandmother, Frances Webber, who was originally from Plymouth and sister of decorated naval brothers from WW2.

boatwithrank.name: Mari
boatwithrank.short_description: Mari is a classic Hillyard yacht built in LIttlehampton

boatwithrank.name: Spray
boatwithrank.short_description: Built by the famous Lancashire Nobby builder, Crossfields of Arnside in 1896 and is one of the last remaining boats from that era that is not only afloat but regularly partakes in boating events all around the Irish Sea.  As well as a regular competitor in the Liverpool and Conway Nobby races. Her sailing adventures include North Wales, Ireland, Scotland, the Cumbrian Coast and not forgetting her years present at the Peel Traditional Boat Festival at Peel on the Isle of Man.

boatwithrank.name: Hypatia
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in teak on oak, with laid pine decks, 'Hypatia' was originally a centreboard yacht, drawing 3'. She is believed to have been sold to Russia in 1936, and returned after the war.

boatwithrank.name: Fortuna lll
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Fortuna III' is a Hillyard 28' wooden Bermudan cutter, built in 1931 and recognised as the sister ship to Arthur Ransome's 'Nancy Blackett'.

boatwithrank.name: Coco
boatwithrank.short_description: Coco is a beautiful, lightly used Cornish Crabber 22, built in 2004 to the usual high spec. by Crabbers of Rock.

boatwithrank.name: Dz
boatwithrank.short_description: Francois Vivier designed "Aber".  High quality vessel kept in show condition. Built for Charles Payton to celebrate his involvement in the Brest and Douarnenez Festivals from 1988.

boatwithrank.name: Mariette
boatwithrank.short_description: Converted to gaff cutter from Bermudan sloop in 2000. She has had her plate removed and full size iroko bilge keels have been added by Robertsons of Woodbridge plus other works by them. The plate case was filled with lead and iron to compensate for the loss of plate weight.

boatwithrank.name: Rowspar
boatwithrank.short_description: `Rowspar’ is an Itchen Ferry yacht built in 1926 by Berthon Boat Co.

boatwithrank.name: Philomena
boatwithrank.short_description: Trailable Gaff cutter, camper sailer. Green hull tan sails.

boatwithrank.name: Tinkerbell
boatwithrank.short_description: Tinkerbell is a Bembridge scow (11ft 3" x 4ft9") built by A.A. Coombes in approx. 1955.

boatwithrank.name: Lady Anne
boatwithrank.short_description: Ferro sheathing has prolonged her active life

boatwithrank.name: Chione T
boatwithrank.short_description: Chione T is a Tradewind Atoll

boatwithrank.name: Gweneth
boatwithrank.short_description: Not to be confused with Gweneth of 1901, a cutter which had been owned by the same person who commissioned this Gweneth of 1911.

boatwithrank.name: Aussie II
boatwithrank.short_description: The first hull was built in 1983 and after being burned, was replaced in 1986.

boatwithrank.name: Zircon
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Zircon' is a 4-tonner, based on a Harrison Butler Zyclon design.

boatwithrank.name: Victoria
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1897 for the Colne River Police (largely funded by the oyster industry), 'Victoria' was originally a clinker half-decker. In 1902 a cabin was added and a few years later her hull was doubled and made carvel. She has a heavy iron centreplate which takes her draft from 2ft 8" to 7 ft 8".

boatwithrank.name: Undine
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Undine' was built 1889 at Menai Straits, by G Edwards to the design of the original owner J.H.Cousins. Typical of her time, she was a "plank on edge" gaff cutter, with clipper bow, narrow beam and heavy lead keel to keep her upright. Her original length on deck was 33', increased to 35' by the addition of 2' to her counter.

boatwithrank.name: Poppy
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Poppy' is a Beg Meil, built as part of a 38 week boatbuilding course at the Boat Building Academy in Lyme Regis.

boatwithrank.name: Duet
boatwithrank.short_description: Owned by the Cirdan Trust, Duet continues her long association with youth sail training, frequently being crewed by young people taking their Duke of Edinburgh Award. She is a fine example of a gaff-rigged yawl, retaining the features of a classic Edwardian yacht.

boatwithrank.name: Petranella
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Petranella' is an Oysterman 16 built in 1979.

boatwithrank.name: Puddleduck
boatwithrank.short_description: Built from American design "Titmouse".

boatwithrank.name: Patience
boatwithrank.short_description: 23' gaff cutter designed and built by first owner Peter Atkins of Poole and launched in 1993.

boatwithrank.name: Oran na Mara
boatwithrank.short_description: Oran na Mara is a powerful little cutter of the Sea Scamp class

boatwithrank.name: Golden Vanity
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Golden Vanity' was built in 1903 for the marine artist Arthur Briscoe and launched in 1908. Following her restoration, she provides sailing opportunities and courses with First Class Sailing.

boatwithrank.name: Hyrst of Eremue
boatwithrank.short_description: The first boat of her class, hull no. 1, 'Hyrst of Eremue' was built in 1999, her name meaning 'Jewel of Yarmouth' in Old English.

boatwithrank.name: Cornubia
boatwithrank.short_description: Cornubia was built for Pilot Morrice in Polruan at Slade’s Yard on the Bristol Channel.

boatwithrank.name: Melisande
boatwithrank.short_description: Built around 1913 as a Royal Navy ship's boat

boatwithrank.name: Speedwell
boatwithrank.short_description: Originally built as a motor oyster dredger for use on the East Coast rivers, 'Speedwell' is now rigged as a ketch and sails on the Solent.

boatwithrank.name: Fly
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1850 as a bawley, Fly is one of only four boats taking part in both the first 1963 and 50th Anniversary 2013 OGA East Coast Races. She came second in 1963.

boatwithrank.name: Grey Seal
boatwithrank.short_description: Grey Seal is a Kattegat 26, hull number 5, completed in 2018-2019.

boatwithrank.name: Minstrel
boatwithrank.short_description: Built at Totnes, Devon, to a commissioned design in 1991, Minstrel has cruised extensively in the Carribean, Maine, Southern Ireland and undertaken two circumnavigations of Britain.

boatwithrank.name: Siola
boatwithrank.short_description: Siola is a Golant Gaffer, sail no. 5.

boatwithrank.name: Wasp of Walberswick
boatwithrank.short_description: She's a real one-off.

boatwithrank.name: Joëlle
boatwithrank.short_description: A Yachting World 5 Tonner, 'Joëlle' was built in 1947 at Philips Yard, Dartmouth.

boatwithrank.name: Coral
boatwithrank.short_description: Built as one of six yachts in Ipswich, 1936, 'Coral' was taken to Ireland after the 2nd World War where she remains.

boatwithrank.name: Emanuel
boatwithrank.short_description: Emanuel was designed and built by Andrew Anderson & Son at Penarth, South Wales. She undertook the first recorded single-handed passage to Newfoundland by the Northern Route in 1934.  She returned via Bermuda suffering dreadful storms soon after leaving St Johns.

boatwithrank.name: Arwen
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1975, Arwen is one of the original Memory 19s, completed at home by her first owner, Hugh Harrison.

boatwithrank.name: Charlotte II
boatwithrank.short_description: Jaap Kraayenhof built Charlotte from 1996 -2003; she is a typical Cape Cod Catboat.

boatwithrank.name: Step Back In Time
boatwithrank.short_description: Step back in Time is a Golant Gaffer launched at the Yarmouth Old Gaffers Festival in 2011.

boatwithrank.name: Shamrock
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Shamrock' is probably the last fully restored working Tamar sailing barge, kept at Cotehele Quay, a National Trust property on the River Tamar, Cornwall.

boatwithrank.name: Almita
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Almita' celebrated her 115th birthday by winning the Swale match in 2021, with 1st in class, 1st visiting yacht and best dressed of the regatta!

boatwithrank.name: Hannah of Rock
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in ply, Hannah of Rock provided the mould for all subsequent mark 1 Cornish Crabbers.

boatwithrank.name: Scala Nimbata
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Scala Nimbata' was conceived, designed and built to sail and row the River Thames from source to tideway.

boatwithrank.name: Constance
boatwithrank.short_description: Designed by Percy Dalton, 'Constance' was built in steel by Edwin Bracken, 1996.

boatwithrank.name: Saorsa
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Saorsa' is a Memory 19, cabin version, built in 1995. She has spent most of her days sailing in Scottish waters from the Isle of Arran and the Clyde to the Solway Coast.

boatwithrank.name: Sheemaun
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1935 by Noble & Co of Fraserburgh, 'Sheemaun' is a gentleman’s motor sailer, conscripted into the royal Navy during World War II, transferred to the Merchant Navy, used as a training ship and a participant in the Queen's Jubilee River Pageant, 2012.

boatwithrank.name: Rigmor von Gluckstadt
boatwithrank.short_description: The Rigmor von Gluckstadt is the oldest seaworthy sailing ship in Germany, originally built as a customs cutter in 1853 she is now a museum ship based on the River Elbe.

boatwithrank.name: Eleanor Mary
boatwithrank.short_description: Eleanor Mary was built in 1988, designed for a friend who wanted a traditional high peaked gaff-rigged cruising yacht.

boatwithrank.name: Miss Ningi
boatwithrank.short_description: A Carra 16 design that has been totally rebuilt as a day boat that can be used for occasional nights on board.

boatwithrank.name: Canowie ll
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Canowie ll' is a Silvers 42' Silver Leaf class motor yacht built in 1933.

boatwithrank.name: Lillian
boatwithrank.short_description: Lillian is a beautiful dinghy .

boatwithrank.name: Flamingo
boatwithrank.short_description: Flamingo is a yacht built in 1930. A major restoration was begun in 1995 and is ongoing in 2014 after two changes in ownership.

boatwithrank.name: Isobel
boatwithrank.short_description: Gaff Sloop. Sail No 9. Outboard engine. Black hull, cream sails

boatwithrank.name: Nell
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nell' was built in 1887 to transport ministers around the Scottish islands which had no resident minister.

boatwithrank.name: Thalia
boatwithrank.short_description: Thalia was built in 1888 and has cruised and has raced extensively on both sides of the Atlantic.

boatwithrank.name: Genesta II
boatwithrank.short_description: Genesta II, previously known as Ching Ching, was originally built as a small cruiser/racing yacht.

boatwithrank.name: Queequeg
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Queequeg' was built by the owner of Smallcraft from a mould he took from a local boat on a visit to the Shetlands.

boatwithrank.name: Cutlass
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Cutlass' is a 47' ketch, built in Norway, 1886, allegedly for the King of Denmark.

boatwithrank.name: Transcur
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Transcur' was built in 1889 as an oyster dredger working on the east coast of England. She is just over 35ft long weighing 12 tons. 'Transcur' was totally rebuilt between 1999 and 2001, when she was relaunched.

boatwithrank.name: PAJ
boatwithrank.short_description: PAJ was bought as a total derelict for her trailer, and then rebuilt with the mainsail cut down to gaff.

boatwithrank.name: E.L.G.
boatwithrank.short_description: E.L.G. is a Maldon Smacks Boat. She was made from a mould taken from Tiny Mite's tender. Tiny Mite OGA no 2733

boatwithrank.name: Reprieve
boatwithrank.short_description: Built around the turn of the century at Newman’s Boatyard, ‘Reprieve’ was one of only two pilot cutters recorded as constructed in Poole, Dorset. Sadly there is no record of her early years other than for some period she was the home of a priest and his family.

boatwithrank.name: Mon Nèg
boatwithrank.short_description: Drascombe Scaffie "Mon Neg"

boatwithrank.name: St Piran
boatwithrank.short_description: St Piran's design is based on the Galway Hooker, Pucan or Gleoiteog type and built in 1994.

boatwithrank.name: Juniper
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Juniper' is a 24' Brock gaff rigged yawl built in 1997 by Bridgend Boat Company.

boatwithrank.name: Swn y Don
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Swn y Don' is a Yachting World People's Boat, winner of the 1950 YW Magazine design competition.

boatwithrank.name: Zingela
boatwithrank.short_description: Zingela is a much traveled Vertue, leaving the UK in 1969 and returning in 1993, having sailed to South Africa and back

boatwithrank.name: Barnabas
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Barnabas' is the only survivor from St Ives of the 1,000-strong fleet of lug rigged seine and drift net fishing boats registered at Cornish ports at the turn of the 19th century. Restored to sailing condition, she is owned by the Cornish Maritime Trust and is undertaking a round Britain passage in 2015.

boatwithrank.name: Marynka of Walton
boatwithrank.short_description: Marynka is a traditional wooden Bermudan sailing sloop, designed and built by Harry Feltham in 1951 at Portsmouth.

boatwithrank.name: Polly of Skippool
boatwithrank.short_description: Very traditional 10 ton cutter.  Winner of CB Trad class award 2018.  Rig heavily influenced by Dyarchy.

boatwithrank.name: Gwenili
boatwithrank.short_description: Gwenili is a very well known gaffer on the East Coast of England, having spent the last 50 years in the Area. She has been well maintained over that time and is a regular participant in racing and cruising events. In 2019, she was sold and taken to Thessaloniki, Greece.

boatwithrank.name: My Quest
boatwithrank.short_description: 1930s 23ft gaff cutter built by Ernest Woods at Horning, Norfolk. One of only two hulls built to a design by Mr G Cozens.

boatwithrank.name: Kelpie 2
boatwithrank.short_description: Kelpie II was home built and launched at Greenwich on the lines of Rani IV, at a cost of just over £75. In over 110 years, she's had just four owners.

boatwithrank.name: L' Atalanta
boatwithrank.short_description: By 1984, she'd had seven name changes eight owners and four engines, but on inspection after 80 years, all the hull timbers seemed to be 1904, Swedish oak!

boatwithrank.name: Puffin
boatwithrank.short_description: Puffin is a Victorian gaff cutter, originally built as a schooner in 1894. She has a clinker hull pitch pine hull, and is currently undergoing a major restoration.

boatwithrank.name: Lazy Wind
boatwithrank.short_description: Lazy Wind has cruised from Chatham to Whitby, the Dutch Frisian Islands, Portrieux, Isles of Scilly and Milford Haven.

boatwithrank.name: Little Millie
boatwithrank.short_description: ‘Little Millie’ is a gaff-rigged GRP Memory 19 built in 1979. She is the open cockpit version, with lifting hatch access to a cuddy below the foredeck. She’s great to sail single-handed with room in the cockpit for the whole family.

boatwithrank.name: Witch
boatwithrank.short_description:
Marine author Basil Lubbock owned 'Witch' from 1913 - 1921. After his first sail he wrote: “Very pleased with the behavior of 'Witch' - showed good speed”. Since 2006, she had been undergoing a major restoration.

Along with a number of other important craft, 'Witch' was lost in a major fire in Cowes Monday 25 January 2016.

boatwithrank.name: Hannah Hambleton
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Hannah Hambleton' was built in 1931 for a member of the Runcorn Hambleton toffee family.

boatwithrank.name: BlueBelle
boatwithrank.short_description: A one-off long-keel auxiliary gaff sloop designed in 1934 but only built in 2006.

boatwithrank.name: Polly Agatha
boatwithrank.short_description: Polly Agatha is an exact replica of the Bristol pilot cutter, Peggy, built in Falmouth, 2007.

boatwithrank.name: Aeolus
boatwithrank.short_description:
Heard 28 completed 2002. Built to the owner's specification. GRP hull with teak superstructure.

Featured in July 2004 Classic Boat with picture on front cover.

boatwithrank.name: Hester
boatwithrank.short_description: Hester was built on Cornish working boat lines.

boatwithrank.name: Agnes
boatwithrank.short_description: The 46' pilot cutter, 'Agnes', launched in 2003, was built on the lines of the top Scillonian pilot cutter of a byegone age, 'Agnes' of 1841.

boatwithrank.name: Little Kingfisher
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Little Kingfisher' was kept in Yarmouth, Isle of Wight after the 2nd World War when she returned from her longest voyage, to the Baltic.

boatwithrank.name: Zeb
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Zeb' is a Carol Ketch with a wishbone rig built in Cyprus in 1964.

boatwithrank.name: Halcyon
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Halcyon' is a Cape Cutter 19 and has been owned from new by Simon Head who took delivery from Nick and Lyndsay Voorhoeve at Bursledon, July 2003. She has been trailer sailed around the UK.

boatwithrank.name: Sowelu
boatwithrank.short_description:
Clinker planked Larch on Oak, Copper fastened, solid Oak Transom. 
17' length on deck, 5'11" Beam
Oak Centre Plate with 10Kg Lead inserts
Gaff Yawl with 156sqft of sail

boatwithrank.name: Nercissa
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Nercissa' has been out of the water since 2011 for a major overhaul. Some of her earlier history is known since her origins in Plymouth as a fishing boat.

boatwithrank.name: Papagena
boatwithrank.short_description: Hull and hull fittings bought from Swallow Yachts, Cardegan. Rig designed and built by Tim Le Mare. Sails designed and built by Richard Bower of Moat Sails, Portland

boatwithrank.name: Lauren
boatwithrank.short_description: A lively little boat with an epoxy ply hull and two masts. Long, slim and light and based on the Shetland Ness Yole which evolved from double-ended Viking boats.

boatwithrank.name: Elizabeth
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Elizabeth', a Morecambe Bay Prawner, was sold to sailing charity, without her rig in 2007.

boatwithrank.name: Betty Alan
boatwithrank.short_description: Under the inspiration of a big Mylne ketch, Jeremy Lines designed this rather smaller (50' on deck) centreboard version for his friend Mark Varvill. Drawn entirely by hand in the traditional manner, with not a millimetre or computer mouse in sight, she is built of inch and a quarter mahogany, glued and screwed to laminated mahogany frames.

builderByBuilder.name: Colne Marine and Yacht Co. Ltd.

boatwithrank.name: Piglet
boatwithrank.short_description: Piglet is a Skipper 17 which has been converted to gaff rig.

boatwithrank.name: Mallard
boatwithrank.short_description: Mallard is a Clovelly Picarooner.

boatwithrank.name: Gwennel
boatwithrank.short_description: Gwennel is a Heard 35, hull number 2, which was bought from Gaffers and Luggers to finish at home but was unlikely never sailed. She is now going through an extensive refit ready for living on in the autumn of 2021.

boatwithrank.name: White Cloud
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1912 by Gann & Palmer in Teignmouth as a Gentleman's Yacht, White Cloud has pitch pine planking on elm frames. Ashore for over 12 years, she was re-launched September 2013 after a thorough restoration by Les Weeks lasting nearly six years. In 2012 Les received a Transport Trust Restoration Award for his work on White Cloud.

boatwithrank.name: Pearl of Beaulieu
boatwithrank.short_description: Cream coloured hull with blue stripe, cream sails, lovely boat

boatwithrank.name: Janty
boatwithrank.short_description: Janty was built in 1939 but registered in 1948, so she probably spent the war sitting on the hard.

boatwithrank.name: Jan Blank
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Jan Blank' is a lifeboat converted to a trailer sailer cabin cruiser.

boatwithrank.name: Island Swift
boatwithrank.short_description: 35' steel gaff cutter launched 1996, a Nick Skeates 35' Wylo with fixed keel, built by John Richardson. Departed Falmouth UK, Septemer 2014, visiting Spain, Portugal, Madeira, Canary Isles, Cape Verde Islands to Martinique (March 2015). Cruised the Caribbean 2015-2016 leaving Antigua May 2016 via Horta, then arrived home to Penzance in July 2016.

boatwithrank.name: Renaissance
boatwithrank.short_description: Built in 1936, 'Martlet' is listed in the Lloyds Register. Pitch pine on oak, she was one of six yachts designed and built by Mr S Upham of Brixham, known as Torbay Quay punts

boatwithrank.name: Rose of Arden
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Rose of Arden' was built by Whisstocks of Woodbridge, Suffolk in 1939 to a design of Dr T Harrison Butler.

boatwithrank.name: Dunlin
boatwithrank.short_description: After two years renovation 1975 - 1977 she was sold by R.G Ward. Lost, mid-Atlantic, 12 September 2004, with owner since 1979, Phil Nerin, being rescued.

boatwithrank.name: Working Yacht 1
boatwithrank.short_description: Built by John Robert Laband in 1991, Working Yacht I is ferrocement with ply and teak deck.

boatwithrank.name: Happy Days
boatwithrank.short_description: Bought as a home completion. Built in 1999.

boatwithrank.name: Juanita
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Juanita' was owned for many years by Dulcie Kennard, first wife of Maurice Griffiths. In the late 1950s, the boat was damaged and sold. In 2016 she was found at Bawdsey and, after restoration in Ipswich joined the East Coast OGA fleet in August 2017.

boatwithrank.name: Helen of Emsworth
boatwithrank.short_description: She is a Cornish Crabber 24 MkV.

boatwithrank.name: Chubby
boatwithrank.short_description: Restored West Wight Scow

boatwithrank.name: Merganser
boatwithrank.short_description: Vertue 47, Merganser is an extremely original Vertue with the classic 'slutter' rig.

boatwithrank.name: Peerie Maa
boatwithrank.short_description: 'Peerie Maa', built in C1930 is a Shetland utility boat, with original rig cotton sails by Jeckells of Lowestoft.

boatwithrank.name: Master Frank
boatwithrank.short_description: Master Frank, launched in 1896, continued to fish commercially until 1978 and, following an extensive restoration project by her current owner, is still seen sailing off the Isle of Man coast.

boatwithrank.name: Straight Across
